msItem.title: The Worcester Fragments
msItem.note: Fifteen leaves of polyphonic music recovered from bindings of MSS. Auct. F. inf. 1. 3 (SC 2747), Bodl. 862 (SC 2730), and Hatton 30 (SC 4076). Interspersed with photostats of other fragments in Worcester Cathedral Library MS. Add. 68 and Brit. Mus. Add. MS. 25031. The MS. is fully described with facsimiles and a concordance of new with old foliations by L. A. Dittmer, The Worcester Fragments, Musicological Studies and Documents 2, Amer. Inst. of Musicology, 1957, and Publications of Medieval Music Manuscripts, no.6, Inst. of Med. Music, New York, 1960. The following list aims to clarify the sometimes confusing relationship between the original leaves and the modern reprocuctions in the volume, and between the various foliations. In addition to the foliations mentioned in the literature, the reproductions of fragments at Worcester have another modern pencil foliation, now erased: this was perhaps used temporarily, before the volume was bound.

Typescript letter from Anselm Hughes to H. H. E. Craster, asking for the flyleaves of MS. Auct. F. I. 3 and Magdalen College, MS. 100, to be removed from their bindings, and for photographs to be deposited at Worcester; dated 23 September 1924.
Typescript letter from Anselm Hughes to H. H. E. Craster, thanking the latter for supplying him with rotographs; dated 30 August 1927

Typescript letter from Luther A. Dittmer to R. W. Hunt, supplying a concordance of the 'Present (Hughes)' foliation and the 'Future' foliation which Dittmer intended to use in his 'forthcoming publication'; dated 22 August 1952.
Brief notes on the contents and foliation, in the hand of Edgar Lobel

supportDesc.extent:
15 leaves, with 25 photostats = vi + 40 leaves 270 200
Much mutilated by binders; dimensions variable.
supportDesc.foliation: Medieval foliation in red ink upper-case roman numerals survives in the earlier part of the volume; at least two modern pencil foliations are present throughout (see under Text).
supportDesc.collation: The leaves do not necessarily come from a single original volume; there are too many lacunae to reconstruct the collation with any confidence, but it seems that quires of about ten leaves were common in the section with medieval foliation: the first quire must have been of 10 leaves, since fols. VI-VII in the medieval foliation are a bifolium; the quire including medieval fols. LXXXII-CI was probably also of 10; and that containing LXXIX-LXXXVIII was presumably of 12 leaves.

decoDesc.decoNote: red and blue initials, a few with flourishing.

history.provenance: Photostats given by the dean and chapter of Worcester and others, 1925

recordHist.source: Typescript description by Bodleian Library staff, revised by Peter Kidd, late 1990s.
